posts.name: Alton Jensen
posts.cooked:
Be able to set a date/time for a message to be sent instead of sending it immediatly…
This is a common feature in most SMS apps. My use case is for when I want to send a message to someone, but don’t want it sent immediately.

For example, it’s my friend’s birthday tomorrow and I want to send him a message. Instead of risking getting busy and forgetting to send it tomorrow (which happens a lot), I compose the message and schedule it to send automatically tomorrow at noon.

link_counts.title: Silent, low priority messages to avoid disturbing the receiver (Silent messages)
Ability to schedule sending of a Poll

posts.cooked:
_AltJ:

My use case is for when I want to send a message to someone, but don’t want it sent immediately.

I love this idea. I already scribble down certain app messages that I want to send at a later point (like asking how some appointment went, or not wanting to app someone at 6am). A scheduling feature would make sending messages easier, but also create a more relaxing experience. Instead of having to recall in the back of my mind when something is due for a follow up, I can just write it and let it go from my mind. (I’m bad at explaining this, but it’s a guiding principle to ‘mind dump’ in many productivity systems like Getting Things Done.)

posts.name: Jeremy
posts.cooked: A friend of mine who uses signal just asked about this and it does seem like a pretty good idea.

posts.name: Hss296
posts.cooked: Yes, I love this feature. It’s very helpful for event organizing/planning, especially for large groups. It’s my favorite feature on the Pulse SMS app and the reason that it took me so long to download Signal. If Signal had this feature, I’d have no use for Pulse anymore so please get on this!
I hope we can revive this request. This would be a great feature in Signal.

posts.cooked:
Where should it be the burden of schedule to appear? On app itself or on Signal server?

Lets dig into details. You compose a message and set schedule on your app and tap on Schedule button. Now what should happen?

  1. Should message be send to Signal server and wait there until time appears and Signal server sends the message.
  2. Should message be saved in Signal client app and waiting there until scheduled time appears and then send to Signal server?

If solution 1) Benefits: You could turn off your client like phone or even more practical your desktop. Challenges:

  • Signal clients and server code should be changed. Less likely to happen.
  • Additional burden on Signal servers. It may yield the server at some specific time like new year when millions of such messages can be triggered.
  • How should user be notified that schedule was really triggered from Signal server? If read indicators are on, then user would receive delivered status. Would that be OK? But what if receiver has reading indicator turned off? You would have no info if message was delivered. Should there be another status to tell sender message was triggered?

If solution 2) Benefits: Probably simpler to implement, because only Signal client code must be changed. Also no burden on Signal servers to do the schedule jobs. Challenges:

  • Your client app has to be turned on when time to send appears and has access to internet connection at that time.
  • If you schedule on WiFi with phone, but when time to trigger message appears suddenly you are on mobile data that can be charged more. Should message be send anyway?
  • If message is not send on scheduled time, like poor connection conditions (or someone only has WiFi internet access, with no mobile data plan), should it be send right after the connection is established? This is somehow reasonable for like you are in elevator for a minute or so, but what if you are climbing in the mountains and not available for many hours/days? Should message still be send when good network condition improves or should there be some kind of time out, requiring user to manually re-confirm (it may defeat the purpose of schedule, but it may not send messages that are useless).

I think scheduled messages would be nice features. I am just saying there are challenges we need to think of and make good compromises.

Harold:

Hi to all, if scheduled message wouldn’t compromise security…could be a good feature.

Can you please explain little bit more, where you see security compromise? Do you maybe mean privacy compromise? Please write more, I would like to understand what are your concerns.

posts.name: Alton Jensen
posts.cooked:
I prefer solution 2.
Regarding the challenges you mention:
1 - By “turned on” I assume you mean have the app up and running. I don’t think the app is required to be turned on, it has a process that always runs in the background. Otherwise, inbound messages would never be received unless you had the app up and running.
2 - I think the message should be sent as if you were composing & sending the message at the moment it is scheduled to be sent. The app shouldn’t have to dig into any phone specific settings to determine whether a message should be sent or not.
3 - Same as #2 - There is functionality already in place for handling poor connections or non-existent connections. I don’t think this should change. Poor connection conditions should be handled the same way they are currently when you try to send a message and it fails due to a connection issue. (It currently alerts you to the error and lets you retry)

One additional benefit to having the Signal client app manage the scheduled messages is that the user could delete the message prior to send time to prevent it from being sent, if desired.

posts.name: Harold Finch
posts.cooked:
HI, totally agreed with Last commit.
What about code? It’s just copy past from other githubcode or more difficult?
That feature could be interesting to reach 1 billion user?

@_AltJ, for signal4phones I also like solution 2 more, but for signal4desktop (I shut-down my home desktop when I don’t need it) solution 2 would not be so useful.

In my humble opinion the easiest way to implement this solution would be, that Signal works with schedule exactly the same as without schedule. So when time is up to trigger a schedule it would behave exactly the same as if message is written and send right now. So answers to my 1, 2, 3 questions are irrelevant.

This solution would work for Signal messages. Should it also work for SMS/MMS? Probably yes, it would be nice.

Harold:

We can start to implement in the first time only for sms ( 90% of my birthdays are outside signal).

In my humble opinion if feature is implemented it will first bi implemented for Signal messages or implemented for both in the same time. I see Signal app to be a Signal messenger application and secondary on Android it also supports SMS.

If feature is going to be added we need to think how it is going to be implemented for: signal4android, signal4ios and signal4desktop. No client should be left out of functionality. Despite I see it more useful for singal4phone.

posts.name: Alton Jensen
posts.cooked:
I’m not completely familiar with how the mobile app and desktop interact behind the scenes. It appears that messages are synchronized between the two. If that’s the case, then scheduled messages could be synchronized in the same way from signal desktop to the mobile app, then handled & sent by the mobile app.

I agree regarding having the same functionality across all platforms and also working with SMS messages sent by Signal.

_AltJ:

I’m not completely familiar with how the mobile app and desktop interact behind the scenes. It appears that messages are synchronized between the two.

Actually they don’t. When you send message to your friend from your phone message gets encrypted with your friend key and send to Signal server. The same original text on your phone gets encrypted with your desktop key and send to the Signal server. Then if you like you can power-off your phone. Power on your desktop and connect to the internet. Message gets pulled down from Signal server. Phone and desktop works like two independent devices, but linked together to both getting the same message. There is no direct phone to desktop sync with messages.

But there are some sync like read receipt and typing indicators. You set on phone and the setting gets delivered to desktop. Actually in this case I am not sure this settings gets directly synced between phone and desktop or by using Signal server as a middleman.

_AltJ:

scheduled messages could be synchronized […] from signal desktop to the mobile app

I like this idea very much. Phone is mostly turned on, but desktop/laptop isn’t, so if schedule is created on desktop, then phone gets responsible to take over the scheduled task.

posts.name: Alton Jensen
posts.cooked:
Thank you for that explanation. I’m glad to understand that process better. How long are messages stored on Signal server?

If the scheduling is going to be handled on the app side of things and the scheduled messages are synchronized through Signal server, then it looks like there will need to be some sort of locking put in place by the client when it sends the message so that other clients don’t duplicate the effort of sending the scheduled message out.

posts.name: Alton Jensen
posts.cooked: But in reality, I’d almost rather keep it simple and have it all be done on the client side without synchronization to other clients. It seems like this would lower the barrier significantly to get this feature up and running. Also, I think that a simpler solution would be easier to implement and cover SMS through Signal too.
